newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: KL overnight interbank rate stays at 6.5/7.0 pct.
newsitem.headline: KL overnight interbank rate stays at 6.5/7.0 pct.

text.p: The overnight interbank rate stayed in the 6.5-7.0 percent range on Tuesday, supported by borrowing by small to medium-sized banks, dealers said.
"The smaller banks seem to be short of funds though trading volumes have not been big," said a dealer at a Malaysian bank. "Seven percent was taken but it has now come off slightly."
Dealers said lenders' reluctance to lend lower amid persistent rumours of a new bond issue had also kept interbank rates steady.
But rates could be pressured again with more funds coming into the market, dealers said.

They said there will be another maturity of a 500-million ringgit Bank Negara bills issue on Friday after bills worth a similar amount had matured last Friday. Both maturities have not been matched by any issue.
In addition there will be a maturity of a 900-million ringgit long term government bond issue on May 15.
Dealers said they expected the central bank to call for more Bank Negara bill issues next week.
Earlier, interbank rates were generally steady with interest focusing on three-month money.
One-week and two-week money was at 6.8/7.0 percent against 6.9/7.1 on Monday, and three-week was at 7.00/10 percent against 7.10/20.
One-month money at 7.25/30 percent, three-month at 7.30/35 and six-month at 7.35/40, were all unchanged.
Interest rate futures on the Malaysia Monetary Exchange were generally higher at the close on expectations of softening of interest rates, futures market dealers said.
Dealers noted buying by foreign players.
The benchmark three-month Kuala Lumpur Interbank Offered Rate (KLIBOR) September contract was up two points at 92.69, or an implied yield of 7.31 percent.
December rose two to 92.68, or 7.32 percent.
March 1998 was up three to 92.61, or 7.39 percent and June 1998 was up four to 92.60, or 7.40 percent.
